She sells fringes, trims and decorations in the Confraternidad Market. She makes earrings, necklaces and bracelets of nickel, nickel silver and wire. She also transports all kinds of different items such as shoelaces, brushes, fingernail clippers, soaps, toothpaste and more from the department of Puno, Juliaca district. Julia is requesting a loan to buy merchandise to sell at her stand. She is grateful and appreciates the help offered through this medium. She is committed to achieving repayment of her debt within the established timeframe.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise to sell at her stand.

loans.name: Vicenta Del Socorro

texts.es: Vicenta del Socorro tiene 40 años, tiene dos hijos. Su actividad económica de es la venta de mercadería en general como ropa, calzado, perfumes, cremas entre otras cosas. Hace más de 11 años que ella decide iniciar este negocio porque no tenía un trabajo estable y necesitaba proporcionarle a su familia el pan de cada día, es así que ella empieza a visitar a sus amigos vecinos y otras personas que le realizaban encargos. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de lápiz labial, polvos, bolsos y calzado. Siempre está soñando con aumentar su inventario y tener su propia tienda.
texts.en:
Vicenta del Socorro is 40 years old and has 2 children. Her main economic activity is selling general merchandise such as clothing, shoes, perfumes, creams, and other items. She started this business 11 years ago because she did not have a stable job and she needed to provide for her family's daily needs. Thus, she started visiting her friends, neighbors and other people and taking orders from them. She requests this loan to buy lip pencils, powders, handbags and shoes. She is always dreaming about how she can increase her inventory and have her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy cosmetics, handbags and shoes

loans.name: Yoni

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenece al banco comunal “MILAGROSA VIRGEN DEL CARMEN II”; Nuestra socia vive en el distrito de Huanchac en la provincia de Cusco, departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. YONNY,  ella tiene 39 años de edad es casada y tiene 1 hijo de 18 años de edad, Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, ella vende ropa de forma ambulatoria, y también vende muebles en la plaza tupac amaru todos los sábados ella tiene un pequeño stand en el cual exhibe sus muebles todos los sábados y también hace a pedidos, muebles de sala comedor y de oficina. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en el material de trabajo para la fabricación de muebles.

La socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Yonny belongs to the communal bank "Milagrosa Virgen del Carmen II." She lives in the Huanchac district in Cusco province, in the department of Cusco. Yonny, who is 39, is married and has a son who is 18 years old. She alternates her activities in the home with her retail business. She sells clothing in the street, and also sells furniture in the Tupac Amaru plaza every Saturday. She has a small stand where she displays her furniture each Saturday, and she also takes orders for living room, dining room and office furniture. She requests a loan to invest in raw materials to product furniture. She appreciates and values the support provided through these means, and pledges to fulfill her payment obligations in accordance with the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in materials used to make furniture

loans.name: María Tenais

texts.es:
María Tenais es una madre de familia de años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el sector Insculas del distrito de Olmos, una zona caracterizada por tener a su población concentrada en pequeñas áreas rurales que distan una de la otra, sus actividades económicas principales son la agricultura y la crianza y venta de animales, pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra ubicada a mas de dos horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace cinco años a la venta de productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes en una bodega instalada en su domicilio, el negocio tiene muy buena acogida ya que la zona donde vive se encuentra alejada de la ciudad y los vecinos siempre acuden a su establecimiento para agenciarse de productos de consumo diario; María es consciente de esta situación, por ello se esfuerza por conseguir productos de calidad y por brindar siempre un buen trato, de modo que pueda seguir trabajando con la misma clientela y por consiguiente, sus ganancias no disminuyan.

Las ganancias que percibe de esta actividad las utiliza para apoyar a su esposo con el sostenimiento de su familia, María desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de mas abarrotes, de modo que pueda captar mas clientes, por este motivo se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

María Tenais es una madre entregada a su familia y que desea seguir creciendo como empresaria para otorgarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. En la zona donde vive ella es muy estimada y conocida por sus vecinos los cuales la consideran una mujer alegre y responsable.
texts.en:
Maria Tenais lives with her children and husband in the Insculas section of the Olmos district, an area whose population is concentrated in small rural zones separated one from another. Her major economic activities are farming and raising and selling animals. She is in the Lambayeque province, located more than two hours form Chiclayo. For five years now she has been engaged in selling basic provisions and groceries in a shop located in her home. Her business is well received, since the area where she lives is far from the city, and her neighbors come to her to pick up items they consume daily. Maria is aware of this circumstance, and thus tries to get quality products and offer good customer service, so as to continue working with the same customers and not diminish her earnings. She uses what she earns from this business to support her husband by supporting the family. Maria wishes to grow her business by purchasing more provisions, so as to attract more customers. For this reason she is making this first request to Edpyme Alternative, for a loan of 1,000 new soles. Maria Tenais is totally devoted to her family and would like to grow as a businesswoman, to offer her family a better living standard. People in her area think highly of her and she is known by her neighbors as a happy, reliable woman.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase provisions to expand her business

loans.name: Angel Francisco

texts.es: Ángel Francisco tiene 52 años, con 2 hijos a su cargo. su actividad económica de Ángel es la venta de de mercadería en general hace mas de  28 años que se dedica a esta actividad, pues siempre le ha gustado ser una persona muy responsable y disfruta el conversar con sus clientes. Por lo que no ha sido fácil ya que tiene mucha competencia pero ninguno ofrece el carisma y simpatía de Ángel. Es por eso que solicita este financiamiento así podrá mantener a sus clientes y comprara una amplia variedad de productos. El sueña con mejorar cada día su actividad.
texts.en:
Ángel Francisco is 52 years old and has two dependent children. For more than 28 years he has had a business selling general merchandise. He has always liked his worked, as he is very responsible and enjoys talking with his customers. Although none of his competitors has Ángel's charisma and charm, he faces a lot of competition for business. He is therefore requesting a loan to serve his customers better by offering a wider variety of products. His dream is to improve his business every day.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Juana Alicia

texts.es: La Señora Juana  está casada y tiene su pulpería ubicada en su vivienda, donde vende diversidad de productos. Hace más de 15 años con esta actividad, y le va muy bien ya que conoce muy bien acerca de este negocio. Tiene 6 hijos pero ninguno depende de ella, y solo ella se dedica a su manutención. Anteriormente solo podía ofrecer galletas y ciertas golosinas que colocaba en una mesa, pero con el paso del tiempo ha logrado mejorar. El crédito será invertido en la compra de golosinas, jugos, detergentes, sopas, galletas y pan para aumentar sus productos a la tienda, es una persona responsable y trabajadora.
texts.en:
Juana is married and sells a variety of products in a small grocery store located in her home. She has had the shop for more than 15 years and it is very successful, as she is knowledgeable in all aspects of the business. She has 6 children but none are financially dependent on her. Previously, her shop was only a table where she offered cookies and other sweets for sale, but over time she has been able to expand her merchandise. She will invest this loan in the purchase of sweets, beverages, detergent, soup, cookies, and bread to increase her stock. Juana is a responsible and hardworking woman.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Dionisio Gabriel

texts.es:
Nuestro socio pertenece al banco comunal “MILAGROSA VIRGEN DEL CARMEN II”; Nuestro socio vive en el distrito de Huanchac en la provincia de Cusco, departamento de Cusco.

Nuestro socio es él  Sr. DIONISIO,   tiene 70 años de edad es casado y todos sus hijos ya son independientes y viven con sus propias familias, el socio vive con sus esposa y es muy alegre, juntos tienen un restaurante en su casa muy conocido en la ciudad del Cusco ellos vende como plato típicos, Nuestro socio trabaja con el banco comunal desde hace 8 años  y 25 años en el negocio del restaurante campestre; Nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para reinvertir en su negocio, el socio desea mejorar la fachada del local y dentro del mismo.

El socio agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Dionisio is a member of the “Milagrosa Virgen del Carmen II” communal bank and lives in Cusco. He is married, 70 years old, and lives with his wife, as all of his children are grown and live with their own families. Dionisio is a very happy man and he and his wife sell local food from a restaurant in their very well-known home. He has has had his restaurant for 25 years and has been working with his communal bank for the last eight. He will use this loan to make improvements to the interior and the exterior of the restaurant. Dionisio greatly values and is grateful for the support he has received in the past, and he is committed to repay this loan in the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Make improvements to the interior and exterior of his business

loans.name: Agusta Renee

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenece al banco comunal “MILAGROSA VIRGEN DEL CARMEN II”; Nuestra socia vive en el distrito de Huanchac en la provincia de Cusco, departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. Renne,  ella tiene 55 años de edad es divorciada y tiene 1 hijo, Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, ella tiene un bar snack en su casa en el primer piso, Nuestra socia trabaja aún para ayudar en los estudios superiores de su hijo, Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en el bar e implementarlo y decorarlo.

Nuestra socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member belongs to the “Milagrosa Virgen del Carmen II” communal bank. Our member lives in the district of Huanchac in the province of Cusco, department of Cusco. Our member is Renee. She is 55 years old, divorced, and has one child, a son. Our member alternates her household activities with her retail business. She has a snack bar on the ground floor of her house. Our member works so that she can help her son with his higher education. Our member is requesting the loan so that she can invest in her snack bar by restocking it and decorating it. Our member is very grateful for the support she is being given through this loan, and she agrees to complete her payments according to the terms of the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in her snack bar by restocking it and decorating it.

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.es: Benedicta, es una mujer ejemplar de 58 años, es madre soltera de dos hijos mayores de edad, quienes ya son independientes y trabajan en Lima, ella solo vive con su padre Norato de 83 años, en su domicilio propio. Poniendo en práctica las enseñanzas de su padre, ella siembra sobre sus terrenos propios todos los productos oriundos de la zona, de esa manera ha logrado trabajar alrededor de 40 años en esta actividad, cosechando así sus productos y comercializándolos en la ciudad de Lima.  Asimismo como es una amante del campo, cría también carneros que lo ceba y que luego son vendidos, obteniendo más ganancias. Lo que más le gusta es disfrutar de la tranquilidad del lugar donde habita, de sus cultivos verdes que inspiran alegría y vida y eso le hace muy feliz. Por  otro lado le apena tener que estar todo el día en la chacra y descuidar a su papá, es por ello que espera instalar su tienda de venta de comestibles en su casa para generar ingresos económicos que le ayuden a cubrir los gastos domésticos, y por supuesto continuar sembrando pero con la ayuda de operarios que pueda contratar. Este es su treceavo crédito con MFP y se encuentra muy entusiasmada de continuar trabajando con su grupo comunal, pues ya conoce su metodología de trabajo. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará algunos productos comestibles para empezar en la venta de productos comestibles en un pequeño espacio dentro de su casa.
texts.en:
Benedicta is an exemplary 58-year-old single mother of two adult children who work in Lima. She lives with her 83-year-old father Norato in her own home. For more than 40 years she has used what she learned from her father and planted native crops on her own fields for later sale in Lima. Since she loves the country life, she also raises goats to sell for more income. Her favorite thing is the peace that abounds in the area where she lives. Seeing her green fields inspires happiness and life inside her. However, it pains her to have to be in the fields all day instead of being able to take care of her father. Therefore, she would like to open a general store in her home to generate income and help with household expenses. She will continue to farm her land, of course, but will hire workers to help her. This is Benedicta's thirteenth loan from MFP and she is very enthusiastic about continuing to work with her communal bank since she already knows all its procedures. She will use this loan to purchase merchandise to begin to set up the shop in a small space in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of merchandise

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: Maria Auxiliadora tiene es madre soltera y tiene 1 hijo de 18 años a su cargo, pues ella siempre busca la forma de sacar adelante a su hijo. Su actividad económica es la venta de ropa y leña, pues de esta manera ha logrado proporcionar el pan de cada día y sufragar los gastos en su familia. Pues las ventas las realiza de manera ambulante ya que solamente así puede obtener una gran variedad de clientes. El financiamiento es destinado para la inversión de pantalones, camisas, faldas, trajes y vestidos. Siempre sueña con tener su propia tienda.
texts.en:
Maria Auxiliadora is a single mother with an 18-year-old son, and she is always looking for ways to support him. She works selling clothing and firewood, and has been able to provide their daily bread and pay for familial expenses. In order to get a wide variety of clients she sells her products in the street. This loan will be invested to buy pants, shirts, skirts, suits and dresses for sale. She hopes in the future to have a shop of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es: Rosa Argentina tiene 40 años de edad. Tiene 3 hijos que están menores de edad a su cargo. Ella se dedica a la actividad económica de venta de comida. Hace más de 8 años que inicio por sus hermanas ya que anteriormente, ellas se dedicaban al negocio, pues ella disfruta mucho este trabajo porque sus clientes disfrutan sus deliciosos platillos, Rosa ha logrado salir adelante a pesar de la competencia, pero siempre está recibiendo a sus clientes con una gran sonrisa. El financiamiento es para la compra de granos básicos, frutas, verduras, bolsas y cubiertos entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Rosa Argentina is 40 years old. She is responsible for her 3 young children. For a living, she sells food. Over 8 years ago, her sisters started the business which they enjoyed greatly because their customers derived so much pleasure from the delicious meals. Rosa has been able to succeed despite the competition, and she always greets her customers with a big smile. Among other items, the loan will be use to buy basic grains, fruit, vegetables, bags, and cutlery.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Paulita

texts.es:
Paulita es una madre de familia de 55 años de edad que vive junto a su familia en el sector Vallehermoso del distrito de Monsefú, un distrito conocido a nivel regional por la producción de artesanía en cerámica y madera y también por sus ferias turístico – religiosas, el lugar se encuentra ubicado a cuarenta minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar en la ganadería desde hace mas de diez años, ella cría vacas en un terreno cercano a su vivienda y aprovecha la leche que éstas producen, vendiéndola a un acopiador de la zona. Los ingresos que le brinda el negocio los utiliza en apoyar a su esposo, que es agricultor, en el mantenimiento de su familia, durante todos estos años estas actividades les han permitido salir adelante y solventar sus gastos familiares.

Paulita desea mejorar la producción de su ganado para así poder percibir mayores ganancias, por eso desea alimentar a sus vacas con alimento balanceado. Para lograr este objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Paulita es una mujer trabajadora y entregada a su familia, su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria y convertirse en acopiadora, para sí percibir mas ganancias y sacar adelante a su familia, en la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos la estiman mucho y la consideran una persona honesta y responsable.
texts.en:
Paulita is a 55 year old mother who lives along with her family in the Vallehermoso sector of the Monsefú district. The district is well known at the regional level for its production of ceramic and wooden crafts, as well as for its religious and tourist festivals. It is located forty minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Paulita has worked in livestock farming for more than ten years. She raises cattle on land close to her home and makes the most of the milk that they produce by selling it to a local middleman. She uses her earnings to help her husband, who is also a farmer, support their family. Throughout all these years, these activities have allowed them to thrive and pay their family expenses. Paulita would like to improve the milk production of her cattle in order to increase her income. For this to happen, she must give her cows a balanced feed. To achieve this goal, she requires her first loan from Edpyme Alternative in the amount of 1000 Nuevos soles. Paulita is a hardworking woman who is devoted to her family. Her biggest dream is to continue to grow her business and become a middleman herself. In this way, she would earn more money and improve her family’s life. In the area where she lives, she is well respected by neighbors and acquaintances for being an honest and responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy balanced feed in order to improve the mild production of her cows.

loans.name: Triwana Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut J. A. is a 27-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut J. is the group leader of a 16-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Triwana Sari (MUK-0024).

Ni Ketut J. is married and has 1 school-aged child.  To making a living, Ni Ketut J. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Ketut J. has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2010, Ni Ketut J. joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Ketut J. is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK in the amount of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Ketut J. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Ketut J. A. (0) merupakan 27 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut J. adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 16 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Triwana Sari (MUK-0024).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Ketut J. sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut J. menghasilkan sekitar 200,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Ketut J. bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Ketut J. meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Santos Eliodoro

texts.es: Santos Eliodoro V. M. de 43 años de edad, se dedica a la elaboración de cómales hechos de barro, los cuales son un utensilio de cocina el cual se utiliza para cocinar tortillas o pupusas en toda la región de Centro  América y México. Aunque en la actualidad no son tan utilizados para cocinar, su comercio es muy bueno, ya que las personas los utilizan como adornos ornamentales para los hogares, colocándolos en lugares como jardines y cocinas, así mismo se dan como regalos, lo que permite que se vendan como artesanías. Santos posee 16 años de comercializar cómales, en Guatajiaga, ubicado en el departamento de Morazán, lugar en el cual también habita junto a toda su familia la cual esta conformada por su esposa y cuatro hijos, los cuales se dedican a ayudar a Santos tanto a elaborarlos como a comercializarlos. Este negocio ha sido heredado de familia, ya que todos se han dedicado a la elaboración de los cómales, lo que los hace unos expertos en fabricarlos. Santos solicita un préstamo a Integral a través del cual, compre mayor cantidad de barro para elaborar más cómales y de esta manera vender más.
texts.en:
Santos Eliodoro V. M. is 43 years old. He makes clay comales, which are used to cook tortillas or pupusas, a thick corn tortilla, throughout Central America and Mexico. Although nowadays they aren't used so much for cooking, his business is very good. People use them for decoration in their homes, placing them in gardens and kitchens. They are also given as gifts, which allows for them to be sold as handicrafts. Santos has been selling comales for 16 years in Guatajiaga, located in the department of Morazán. He also lives there with his whole family made up of his wife and four children. They help Santos make and sell the comales. This business has been passed down to him through the family, since all of them have made comales and they are experts in producing them. Santos is asking Integral for a loan to buy a greater quantity of clay to make more comales and thus sell more.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clay

loans.name: G.s. Rafaela Herrera Ii Group

texts.es: Este Grupo Solidario Rafaela Herrera II, está conformado por Zaida del Socorro y Emeteria. Ellas son personas muy trabajadoras, las dos tienen sus propios negocios. Zaida se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general y Emeteria se dedica a la venta de ropa, pues las dos tienen la necesidad de aumentar su inventario, para Emetria es un poco más difícil ya que tiene dedicarle tiempo a su hija ya que ella no puede valerse por sí sola es por eso que además ella tiene que sacar el tiempo para visitar a sus clientes. Ellas solicitan este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima.
texts.en:
The Rafaela Herrera II Group has two members, Zaida del Socorro and Emeteria. They are very hardworking women who both own their own businesses. Zaida sells general merchandise and Emeteria sells clothing. Emeteria has a bit more difficulty because she has a daughter who needs her support and this means she has less time to visit her customers. They both need to increase their stock of merchandise so they are requesting a loan for working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sombang Lestari Group

texts.en:
Ni Kadek P. is a 32-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Kadek is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 'Sombang Lestari' (MUK-0025).

Ni Kadek is married and has 1 infant child.  To make a living, Ni Kadek owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Kadek has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Kadek joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Kadek is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK in the amount of 1,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Kadek plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Huy Yeng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of fifteen people who are living in Trapeang Trayueng village in Takeo province. They will use their loan for different purposE. that can improve their businessE. in the future. 

Mrs. Huy Y. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She and her husband, Mr. P. Phav, are farmers who own half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. They try to work hard in their field, but they can earn only a little money. So to improve family living conditions, they want to start a new business, but they do not have enough money for this. Thus, Mrs. Huy Y. is seeking a loan to buy some piglets for breeding. She is a mother of a child who is twenty-one years old.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Medelyn

texts.en:
Medelyn M. wishes to grow her “bangus” (milk fisk- national fish) fry (fingerlings) buying and selling business to increase its earnings and augment her husband’s small and sporadic income as a hired laborer. This way, she will be able to enhance her capacity to supporting the needs of her four children whose age range is from five to 16 years old, especially their education. Presently, Medelyn’s eldest and second child have stopped studying because she and her husband didn’t have enough income to support them. 

With Medelyn’s  “bangus fry” buying and selling business, given a large amount of loan for working capital, she hopes to purchase a large volume to accommodate the increasing demand of her customers who culture “bangus” for selling. 'Bangus' is one of the kinds of fish Filipinos most love, and it is served in most restaurants. For Medelyn, this business has been a great source of income for her family and has been providing them with many things they need in life.  Through its proceeds, she hopes that someday life for her and her family may be easy and enjoyable.

loans.use: To purchase large volume of "bangus fry" to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Roem Koem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people who live in Krang Dai village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan group. They are going to use their loan for different purposes that can improve their families' living conditions. 

Mrs. Roem K. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her rice field has infertile soil and she does not have enough rice seed to grow. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Roem K. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed. She is a widow with a child who is a rice mill laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Juanita's Group

texts.en:
Juanita D. is from the village of Brgy.Aurora, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Juanita is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juanita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Juanita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Juanita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Juanita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mrs. Sophal Part Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people make up this village bank loan group and they live Kampeaeng Tboung village in TaK. province. Mrs. Sophal P. is the village bank president, selected by all the members who will each use their loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Chan Nung, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice on to support their family. Aside from farming, her husband is a cow middleman too. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve her husband’s business, Mrs. Sophal P. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for resale. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are farmers, while the others are attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for resale

loans.name: Deona Ann's Group

texts.en:
Deona Ann M. is from the village of Brgy.Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 31 years old. Deona Ann is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Deona Ann is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Deona Ann owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Deona Ann has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Deona Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Deona Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Deona Ann is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Deona Ann from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Regina's Group

texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Regina G.'s Group.

Regina is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Regina owns & operates a general store. While not her only means of generating revenue, the main source of income comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Regina has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Regina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Regina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Regina is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product selection. This will be the ninth loan Regina has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product selection

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthorn Khut Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of eight people who live in Cheav Bdei Khang Kaeut village in Takeo province. They will use loan for different purposes that can improve their businesses in the future. Mrs. Chanthorn K. is the village bank president, meaning that she has been selected by all the members as the leader of their group. She is a farmer who owns one hectare of land where she cultivates rice to support her family. Her problem is that her rice field is infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Chanthorn K. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide and with the rest of the loan, she wants to plow her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Rortana Hun, is a taxi driver and they have a child who is one year old. Mrs. Ret Nouv is a group guaranty so she is presented in the photo too.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey R. (pictured above) and her husband Mr. Meun Mak live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have three children, one son and two daughters. All of them are in school. 

Srey has been a silk weaver for 30 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who in turn sells in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a construction worker for two years. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $400 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Jocelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jocelyn G. is from the village of Bannawag. She is 41 years old. Jocelyn is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jocelyn G.'s Group.

Jocelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood product, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 20000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the eighth loan Jocelyn has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn O. (shown in the photo), 32, and her husband Mr. YO. Kan, 35, have been married since 1996 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Three of them are in school. They are living across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sarorn has been selling fish for 10 years. Her husband has been driving a horse cart for five years. Besides these businesses, the couple also farms.

Sarorn is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her farm

loans.name: Marcelina's Group

texts.en:
Marcelina L. is from the village of San Mariano. She is 53 years old. Marcelina is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marcelina L. Group.

Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marcelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan Marcelina has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sokunthea's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of five people who live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sokunthea N. is the group leader, selected by all the members, who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectares of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family living. She is a pig breeder, too. Her husband, Mr. Savuth Sou, is a laborer. Her problem is that the soil in her rice field is infertile. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Sokunthea N. is seeking this loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will buy pesticide, gasoline, and hire a plow machine. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending in local public school, while the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
For the second time since becoming a member of ASHI in 2009, 27-year-old Joan R. is requesting a loan. She was able to repay the full amount of her last loan on time. Though her variety store has not been sustained, its small profit somehow provided her family with the necessities. Joan is just sad because she has allowed a lot of people to purchase items she sells on credit, expecting that she could be paid back. Instead of regret, Joan feels happy to have had that experience, because from it she learned about managing and dealing with costumers. She also learned that her 24-year-old husband who is a driver will still support her, even in her disappointments. Now, Joan and her husband have decided to use this loan she is requesting to start up a hog fattening business.

Hog fattening is a kind of business wherein, after four months of raising or fattening hogs, the hog will be sold to people in their village or in the market, either alive or slaughtered. The larger the volume of hogs being sold, the larger the profit. Therefore, Joan can put up a savings fund for her four children whose age range is from one to seven years old. Through this she hopes to support their education until they graduate from college, and hopefully they will have a better life in the future.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feeds for fattening

loans.name: Nerissa's Group

texts.en:
Nerissa A. is from the village of Maluno Sur. She is 43 years old. Nerissa is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nerissa A. Group.

Nerissa is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nerissa owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal products such as perfumes and watches in the local community. Nerissa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nerissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nerissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nerissa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Nerissa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

texts.ru: Холов Шукрулло проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 40 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, занимается растениеводством. Сам Шукрулло имеет среднее образование. Занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. В этой области уже 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Shukrullo K. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 40 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife is in agriculture. Shukrullo has secondary education and does animal husbandry. He breeds cattle at home and has been in this field for fifteen years. He is taking out the loan to buy large cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
64-year-old Fe E. is one of the ASHI center’s strongest foundation. She became a member in 2005 and has been a model to the rest of the members in the ASHI center she has belonged to since then. In spite of poverty, Fe has been very productive and has been a very strong support to her husband’s livelihood, which is fishing. Through the loan she received from ASHI, she has invested in a motorized fishing boat for her husband and son to manage. She has also been able to have her own "sari-sari" store business. At times, Fe and her daughter were the vendors of the fish her son and husband caught from the deepest parts of the ocean. Looking back at the times when her children had no families of their own yet and she was the one supporting their needs and education, her happiness is undeniable. She realized how each one of them cooperated and participated in improving their standard of living. 

Presently, the fishing business of Fe and her husband still goes on the same, as does her "sari-sari" store, where she sells foodstuffs, beverages and grocery items. Her two sons are also fishermen and their wives are helping them sell their fish. Aside from enjoying the beauty of the crystal clear water of the ocean that lies not more than 80 meters away from their house, Fe and her family also enjoy the opportunity of getting a loan through ASHI and growing their fishing and fish selling business. Since she has no more children depending on her, Fe wants to grow their fishing, "sari-sari" store and fish selling business to make its profit stable, to start a savings fund intended for the renovation of their house, and to help her grandchildren as well.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear, grocery items and foodstuffs

texts.en:
Lena is 47 years old. She is married with one child aged 20 years old. She is a farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale Town. She has been practising mixed farming for the last 30 years. Her main produce is vegetables which she sells at the local market. Lena also earns income from a hotel that she operates in the same area. 

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes.20,000 to start a poultry project. Before venturing into poultry farming, Lena was specializing in maize and dairy farming. The excess income from this loan will enable her and her husband to live happily as their child is now independent. Her main challenge in this business is financial constraints. In future, she hopes to diversify her business by selling chicks at the local market.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: Ergashova Marpathon Group

texts.ru:
Эргашова Марпатхан 56 лет. Она замужем и мать 1  сына. Ее супруг находится в РФ на заработках. Сын работает работает менеджером в компании FedEx. Клиент занимается земледелием, выращивает обычно хлопок. В бизнесе помогает сын. Кредит нужен для закупа цемента и древесины для ремонта дома.

Гулхумор, 38, замужем. Супруг также на заработках в России. У нее трое детей: дочери 18 лет, сыновьям 14 и 11 лет. Дочь помогает по хозяйству, сыновья учатся в школе. Клиентка занимается животноводством. Цель кредита - закупить бычка для откорма и реализации.

Гулзадахон, 36, разведена. У нее 3 детей: сыну 12 лет, дочери 9 лет, также с ней проживает ее мать - пенсионерка. Гулзадахон занимается оптовой реализацией овощей и фруктов. Цель кредита - увеличить товарооборот в виде овощей и фруктов.

Ферузахон, 36, разведена. У нее 2 сына, оба учаться в школе. Клиентв этом году посадила хлопок, первую прополку сделала, также в огород посадила помидоры, огурцы и лук. Кредит нужен для закупа минеральных удобрений для хлопчатника.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Marpatkhon E. is 56 years old. She is married and is a mother of one son. Her husband is now working in the Russian Federation. Her son works as a manager in FedEx. She is in agriculture and grows cotton. Her son helps her in this business. She needs a loan to buy cement and wood to repair her house. Gulhumor is 38, she is married. Her husband also works in Russia. She has three children: her daughter is eighteen years old and her sons are fourteen and eleven. Her daughter helps her in the household, her sons go to school. The client also does animal husbandry. The purpose of the loan is to buy a calf for feeding and resale. Gulzadahon is 36, she is divorced. She has two children: her son is twelve and her daughter is nine. Her elderly mother also lives with her. Gulzadahon does wholesale of fruits and vegetables. The purpose of the loan is to increase the sales of fruits and vegetables. Feruzahon is 36, she is divorced. Her two sons go to school. She has sown cotton this year, has done the first plow and also sowed tomatoes, cucumbers and onions. She needs the loan to buy mineral fertilizer for the cotton.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cement and wood

loans.name: Shirley's Group

texts.en:
Shirley A. is from the village of Danipa. She is 35 years old. Shirley is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shirley A. Group.

Shirley is single. To make a living, Shirley owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirley has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Shirley from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Musabaeva's Group

texts.en:
It is a general principle that regimes and governments change, but the lives of ordinary people always depend on the personal efforts and endeavors of each citizen. Rulers suppose that if business is prospering it is due to their policies and regulations. Well this is true, but to a small extent, for success always lies on the shoulders of each individual. The heroes of our story are namely those individuals who are aware of the current situation and prefer to take action towards changing their lives for the better rather than just waiting until a good politician comes to change their lives. 

R. Musabaeva is the leader of this group. She is twenty-five years old and lives with her family in the city of Karabalta. Her husband works at a construction site and R. stays at home because she has two small children and a household. She breeds cattle and sells milk. In fifteen years of cattle breeding, she has managed to increase her monthly income to $320. Now, she is hoping to obtain this loan in order to buy kitchen furniture.
 
R.’s partners are:
N. Temirova, 22, is from Karabalta. She has a four-year-old child. Her husband is a lieutenant in a military unit. N. is a housewife. Nevertheless, knowing the value of education, she is studying in college by correspondence. She needs this loan to pay for her college tuition. 
A. Ryspekova, 26, is divorced. She has a five-year-old daughter. She raises cattle, sells milk and grows strawberries. Her parents and brother always provide help, looking after cattle and selling the strawberries. A. has a fairly high income, according to local scales, of $380 per month. She hopes to obtain this loan to buy cattle for breeding.
T. Esenova, 59, is the mother of four children. She and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. Due to this activity, they were able to help their children get on their feet and get married. T. needs this loan to buy some furniture. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy kitchen furniture

loans.name: Mir Habib

texts.en:
Mir Habib, son of S. J., lives in the 12th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 52, married with five children, two sons and three daughters. Both his sons are college students and he is helped mostly by his elder son. His daughters are school students.

Mir Habib is a very hard-working man and is responsible for paying all the house expenses. He works seven days a week in his retail shop where he sells different kinds of products to earn money. He has requested an individual loan to purchase more stocks such as eggs, beverages and sanitary products to sell. He hopes to expand his business and to be the most popular business dealer.

loans.use: To purchase eggs, beverages and sanitary products to sell

loans.name: Nazir Ahmad

texts.en:
Nazir Ahmad, son of A. K., lives in Bagrami, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a young man aged 24 and still single. He has a carpentry shop where he is busy seven days a week from 6:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

Nazir Ahmad likes to support his family members and to also save for his future. He needs the loan to purchase good quality wood and to design more wonderful furniture according to his clients' requests. He expects to make his repayments on time and to join for another loan cycle very soon to progress more.

loans.use: To purchase good quality wood and to design more wonderful furniture

loans.name: Sochida

texts.ru: Имомова Сочида проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 34 года. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Образование - среднее. Сочида, портниха. Она в основном шьет платье для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для покупки ткани и ниток.
texts.en:
Sochida I. lives in the Rudaki region. She is 34 years old. She is a widow and has two children. She has secondary education. Sochida is a seamstress. She mainly sews dresses for sale. She has been doing this for six years now. She is taking out the loan to buy fabrics and threads.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and threads

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B. is from the village of Basagan, Katipunan. She is 57 years old. Evelyn is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business providing repair services to local community members. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Evelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Lal Gul

texts.en:
Lal Gul, the son of S., is a resident of the 16th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 40 years old, married and the father of four children who are all school students. He has a shop where he sells electrical materials like bulbs, power cords, tube lights, etc.

He needs the Kiva loan to purchase more electrical equipment for his shop to attract more clients and to increase his income. He is confident that he will make his repayments on time and that he will join for a second loan cycle so he can progress more.

loans.use: To purchase electrical equipment to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira B. would like to invest in a motorized fishing boat for her husband’s fishing business through a loan she is presently requesting. She would like to grow her fish selling business with the help of her husband to support her dreams for her family. 

It was in the year 1998 that she became a member of ASHI. Then her dream of having her own income generating activity and a source of income came true as it is financed by the loans she received through the institution she became a member of.  By buying and selling fish directly to people around the village, the whole town, and in the market, Elvira has able to support the basic needs of her family, especially her seven children whose ages now ranges from four to 24 years old. Aside from the financial support of her second husband who is a fisherman, Elvira is very much thankful for the love he gives not only to her and their own four children but also to her two children from her earlier broken marriage as well. With him, and with the increasing amount of loans Elvira can access through ASHI, she is hopeful that one day, her children will enjoy their lives and that access to their basic needs such food, clothing and education is no longer limited.

loans.use: To purchase a motor fishing boat.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Evelyn C., 51 years of age and married, is a resident of Garang, Tangub City. She is married to Danilo C., a carpenter, and they are blessed with 11 children, only one of whom is still at school. To help her husband support their family, Evelyn decided to engage in business. She has an existing sari-sari (variety) store located at her house. She has managed her business for the past 27 years and is earning an average net income of not less than PHP2,400 a month which is so helpful to her family's income.

Evelyn has been able to access multiple loans with a previous loan amount of PHP13,000. For her 11th loan, she is requesting an amount of PHP12,000 to add to her capital for her existing sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used to improve her family's living conditions, to meet their basic needs and for savings for future use.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital for her existing sari-sari store

texts.en:
Burhanudin is the group leader of the Gul Arghawan group. He lives in the 1st district, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives in a household with five other members, his wife and his four children. His children are school students. He is a butcher and has a butcher shop. He works hard there and all his family members benefit through the income he generates. 

Burhanudin needs the loan to purchase goats, cows and other animals for slaughtering and also to expand his business. He hopes to progress and open another shop in future next to his current one.

loans.name: Tseepil

texts.en:
Tseepil S., 38, is married and the mother of two children. She and her family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent) in Hovd province, Mongolia. Tseepil operates a raw material trading business in her town. Her daughter, Amarbaysgalan, attends a local secondary school. Her son, Amarjargal, attends a local primary school. During the day, Tseepil operates her raw material trading business at a market called Han-Ord. She has been operating her business since 2004, and has steadily expanded it.

Tseepil purchases the raw materials every week and resells them for a profit. Raw material businesses require a large amount of working capital, therefore she cooperates with two other people who run the same type of business. They share the profits depending on the contributed amount of money from each person. In addition, Tseepil grows vegetables for her family's usage. She is a very hard-working person and is focused on the future. Currently, the most important thing to her is to purchase more raw materials for her business. Tseepil is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more cashmere for her business.

loans.use: To purchase cashmere

texts.en:
Torpeky is a member of the Gul sorkh group. She lives in the 1st district, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and the mother of four children, two sons and two daughters. They are all studying at school. She is a tailor and has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

Torpeky is a good tailor and can sew different kinds of clothes, so she is quite popular in her area. She needs the loan to purchase cloth, different kinds of threads, large needles and scissors. She hopes to progress in the future and to open a shop instead of working from home.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, different kinds of threads, large needles and scissors

loans.name: Chak

texts.en:
Mr. Chak M. is a married father, blessed with five children, four of whom are single and one who is now married. To help with the family’s living expenses, three of his daughters are employees in the garment industry.

To pursue a daily income, Mr. Chak M. arises early and goes to the forest where he buys firewood in bulk from forest people and delivers it to sell from his house. His wife, who appears in the photo here, breeds a few pigs to earn a living. Mr. Chak M. will be using his first loan to purchase a plot of land, where he will build a new house so his married child can live separately.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to build a house

loans.name: Ofelia's Group

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

In 2006, Ofelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ofelia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the products offered. This will be the eighth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the products offered

loans.name: Enhtsetseg

texts.en:
Enhtsetseg N., 33, lives with her son in Hovd province, Mongolia. Two years ago, she was divorced from her husband and now lives with her son in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). Her son attends kindergarten. Currently, Enhtsetseg operates a grocery store in her town. She has been running her grocery store since 2002, and has steadily expanded her business. She has gained significant experience over the past eight years and has built a loyal customer base. Her product sales are quite good.

Enhtsetseg has been planning to operate a clothing trading business in addition to her grocery store business. She has been working hard to provide a better life for her son. She has a great business mind and is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan so she can operate a clothing trading business in addition to her current business.

loans.use: To open a clothing trading business

loans.name: Mariecris

texts.en:
Mariecris T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 22 years old, married and has two infant children. To make a living, Mariecris owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Mariecris has been engaged in her business for over two years now.

In 2006, Mariecris joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mariecris is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Petronilla Tagbas Group

texts.en:
Petronilla B T., aged 53, is from the village of Senor, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Petronilla B is married and has three adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Petronilla B has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Petronilla B joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Petronilla B is requesting a new loan of 2,500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the third loan she has taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and provide working capital

loans.name: Ream

texts.en:
Ream P., 55, is a hard-working woman and a determined mother blessed with five children. Three of her children are now married and live independently, while the other two are single and help to be responsible for their family by working at various jobs. Ream P. has been selling a few groceries from her home. She sells items that she buys in bulk on credit from her market suppliers. She also repays the income to her suppliers when she has sold nearly all her products.

Ream P.'s husband is a local fisherman. She is taking out her loan to buy a boat for her husband to make fishing easier.

loans.use: To buy a boat

loans.name: Batsuuri

texts.en:
Batsuuri S. is 61 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). His youngest daughter, Oyun-Erdene, is a university student. Batsuuri operates a water trading business in his town. He buys water and resells it, delivering with his horse cart to the local cafes, organizations and individuals. 

Batsuuri started his business in 2005 with a working capital of 10,000 MNT. With a lot of hard work and determination, his working capital today is 1,000,000 MNT.  Over the past five years, he has built a loyal customer base. Since he started his business, he has been providing money for his family expenses and paying his child's university tuition fees. 

Batsuuri has a good personality and has very good communication skills. He says, “My dream is one day to create my own well in order to provide my service to more customers.” He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a car for his business, which will be used to transport water to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a car for delivering water

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda M. is from the town of Talibon. She is 28 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Roda makes and sells "halo-halo", a popular Filipino dessert and also cooks other foods that she sells in her community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years. 

In 2004, Roda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Roda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase ingredients and additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is 42 years old. He is married and has five children between the ages of 6 and 14 years. All of the children attend school. Erick is a farmer from Rift Valley Kenya near Litein town. He has been farming for twelve years and selling his milk and tea to the local market. He also earns income from the sale of vegetables from his farm. He was employed before he ventured into the farming business.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality cow that will produce enough milk and earn him enough income to provide for his family. His main challenges in this business are lack of enough market for his milk and poor transportation that has led to delays in getting the milk to the market. In the future he would like to increase the number of his dairy animals so as to  increase his milk production.

He says he would like to get a larger loan in the future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Manal

texts.en: manal 21 6 kids

loans.use: to purchase wood and supplies

loans.name: Evangeline's Group

texts.en:
Evangeline V., aged 32, is from the village of Brgy. Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Evangeline is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:
